title: Chihuly Garden and Glass, Seattle
review_list:
What a unexpected treat this was for my wife and I. We did not expect such beautiful art dispalyed in the finest of displays. I highly recommend visiting, especially together with the Space Needle. Just awesome

My daughter forced me to go but I was amazed to see the huge blown glass displays. There so much to see that we must have been there well over an hour.Great place to get pictures.

This was somewhere we saw and went to on a whim - and it was totally worth it! Such a cool exhibit, really enjoyed seeing everything. I'll be honest, based on what I overheard from the 'guide', I'm glad we walked through without one.

So glad I made time to run over to this museum during a business trip. The talent on display is absolutely amazing and some of the pieces are downright breathtaking. Will absolutely make a return trip next time I'm in town.

I enjoyed walking in the garden and enjoying the view, the fresh air, and sometimes street performers will play complimenting music just outside of the garden area which adds to the atmosphere. The art inside the museum is spectacular! How he can create such amazing chandeliers is beyond my comprehension. So beautiful!

My friend wanted to go to this attraction. A bit pricey though. You have to pick a time you want to visit. I didn't know very much about this artist but his vision & creation are just stunning! The glass art is so intricate and the colors are so vivid!! Apparently the garden exhibit change quite a bit. It was...


More  



The photos inside the museum I took with my iPhone are like postcards! The glass art pieces are amazing! Outdoor garden photos do not capture the beauty of seeing this in person

Got combined tickets for the space needle and Chihuly. Went up the needle, which was neat but nothing to write home about and then was treated to this artistic display of color and texture. His pieces are gorgeous and how they are displayed is equally stunning. The cherry on top was lunch at the café at the end of the...


More  



For years I put of a visit to the Chihuly Garden and Glass. I just couldn't compel myself to pay for a visit. Based on the view from the outside, I just didn't think there would be enough of a draw to justify the entrance fee.
Wow ... I was wrong. So wrong.
After one visit, the museum has become...


More  



Next to winter, glass is my first love. And Dale Chihuly is its Messiah. What my other idol Frank Lloyd Wright was to architecture and design, Washington native Dale Chihuly is to glass. This is a MUST see if you're ever in Seattle. I was so impressed, I bought a membership so I can come back as often as I...

title: The Museum of Flight, Seattle
address: 9404 East Marginal Way South, Seattle, WA 98108
review_list:
Nice layout, good volunteers but a bit much unless you really like planes. Cafe was good for the venue. First or last Thursday is free, can't remember which.

Located on East Marginal Way and a little difficult to find, the Museum of flight is a wonderful place to take your family. I have been here a number of times with my kids school trips and I never get tired of seeing the many exhibits.

Nice staff, good museum and interesting movie. From city center to the museum about 30 minutes by bus. If you have a rented car, could be more convenient.

An outstanding museum for flight buffs. The F-18 simulator is awesome, as are the standing displays in the great hall. The WWII exhibits are excellent. This is a must-see for any out-of-town visitors who have even an ounce of interest in aviation. Often the cheapest way to go if you have 4 adult guests is to buy the Navigator level...


More  



Unless you hate airplanes.
The collection of war planes is astounding. From WW-1 bi-planes to WW-2 fighters, this museum has it covered.
The jet collection is amazing. The Blackbird was most impressive. Plus, you can just in a cockpit or a flight simulator to see and feel what it would be like to fly one of these.
The Big Red...


More  



This is a place you need some serious TIME to enjoy... otherwise you'll miss a LOT of the history hanging above your heads!! The outdoor exhibits are fantastic... aircraft you could only see on television or read about in books? Here you can actually TOUCH most of them. I will be back to enjoy again. Kids (big and little) will...


More  



Can spend a half day, close to the SeaTac area. The museum has some very exhibits. Concorde, airforce one and boeing dreamliner planes visit is a must. Very nice layout.
Gift shop and eating areas are pretty good too...
Kids have a special play area.
Simulation cockpits for older kids for rides and get somewhat real experience of being in...


More  



This is a place to visit, with some history about aircraft from olds to new ones. Nice for kids and adults that like planes.

This is a wonderful museum for young and not-so-young alike. There are multiple different sections...information about war heroes, a reproduction of an early manufacturing facility, fascinating planes on display. You can spend hours here and do it again a month later.

This museum is right across the street from one of Boeing's facilities (called the "Development Center"), and it is very rich in aerospace history. Lots of great aircraft inside a very large museum. I was lucky enough to actually stay on an overnight sleep over in the museum with my son's Cub Scout Troop.
Great displays inside, with some you...

title: Washington State Ferries, Seattle
review_list:
We dragged our feet to take this adventure my husband planned. What a treat! We loved the beautiful ride!! It was a highlight!!

No matter how many times I ride the Washington State ferries I feel like I'm taking a mini vacation. It's fun to explore the boat and stand outside and let the wind try to blow me over (it was winter on my last ride).

Even with long lines, they keep moving all the time. Have used this twice, good experiences watching the city of Seattle come into view for some great photography.

For $8.10 round trip (for foot passengers) you can get a wonderful view of Seattle, have a pleasant 40-minute cruise (each way) and explore the small town near the ferry landing on Bainbridge Island. This is a nice half day type activity. Try to go when the weather is nice.

We enjoy parking on one side of the water and taking the Ferry to the other side. The ferries themselves are not much to speak of but the views from the ferry are spectacular especially on a beautiful sunny day!

I used to think that Washington state had the best ferry fleet anywhere.
If you get a chance ride one of the BC ferries and see how a properly funded and managed marine highway system really works.
Much like any other result of partisan politics, our Washington state system is just sad, mismanaged and bogged down in bureaucracy.
Too bad,...


More  



Washington State runs one of the largest ferry systems in the world. The boats are efficiently run, safe and although most rides are brief, fun to be on. Virtually every "run" whether 15 minutes or multi hour up to Sydney British Columbia is full of great scenery, sometimes including the icon species of Puget Sound, the Orca whale.
Many Washingtonians...


More  



Enjoyed my recent trip from Kingston to Edmonds. On time and spacious boat. I always enjoyed the Spokane and this time was no different.
I used to ride the ferry system daily, from Colman dock in Seattle to Bainbridge Island every day. Commuted by boat for 8 years.
It lost its mystique pretty quickly. As a tourist or occasional business...


More  



There is nothing like taking a ferry ride on a warm summer day. If you are lucky, you might even see an Orca pod. It is a great value if you go as a walk-on.

If you are ever in the Seattle area there is one thing you must do, ride the ferries. I prefer the Seattle to Bremerton trip, or for a longer one, go to Victoria Island.
Why a ferry ride you ask. Because it is as Seattle as the subway is New York. Not to mention the views are terrific. The sound...

title: Pike Place Market, Seattle
address: Between Pike and Pine sts. at First Ave., Seattle, WA 98101
review_list:
It's what you've seen in the movies and much much more. Very good for a romantic get a way or to drag the kids to. The place has like 3 or 4 levels and some great views of the water.

Everyone can enjoy the Pike Place Market. It's a great place to see what the Pacific Northwest has to offer in the way of people and products!

The market place is fantastic! Fresh fish, fresh flowers, fresh fruit and veggies! Great book shops and very friendly staff! When in Seattle, I always make my way down to the market in the early morning, watching the stalls set up and before it gets busy.

I enjoyed mostly because I love the ocean. I love the open market and all the fresh fish. They also give you options to send stuff with one day shipping.
There are many little shops and also a mini swap meet style sales.
The "original Starbucks" is not the orginal but the relocated Starbucks and is small but they have...


More  



Take a walk around. So much to see. Weather doesn't matter. Make sure to take a trip down post street alley.

I loved walking through the market, even with the fish smell. The flower bouquets are beautiful and reasonable.

We only had a few hours to spend in Seattle on a Saturday morning, so decided to walk over to the market from our hotel. My wife loves markets so we have been to many of them in different places around the world. This is the best! A great place to spend a few hours. We wish we had a...


More  



We visited the market on Christmas Day. It was a lot of fun watching the fish people throw them across the room. Lots of restaurants in the area.

I've been here a hundred times and it's always fun. I always get the mini doughnuts and stop to watch the fish throwers. It's very crowded and pickpockets are rampant.

The venders in the market are authentic, especially the food. Living near the market is a wonderful way to source fresh, local food.

title: Safeco Field, Seattle
review_list:
Using public funds to suppliment a billionaires dream, Safeco is a great place to watch Baseball and Soccer. The view lines are impeccable and the park is perfectly maintained. Now if only the incompetent Mariner management could put a winning team together?

While the food is way overpriced, you cannot beat the setting - especially on a warm summer's eve if you are on the east side of the stadium looking out at Puget Sound. You can see well from every seat.

Always a great outing to see the Ms play! The field and its environment (food, exhibits) are great and constantly bring amazement as they are in all kinds of places.

Nice field! There is a great hotel nearby called the Silver Cloud that has a jucuzzi and heated pool on the rooftop and a great view of the field!

Of course this is one of the top baseball parks in America. Others have spoken eloquently of its features and beauty. My review focuses on how the "baseball fan" can get the most out of the Safeco Field experience
1. Get there 21/2 hours before 1st pitch and enter through the "Pen" Gate, located on the north side of the...


More  



I love Safeco field the home of the Mariners. Good seats abound at all price points although to take a family of 4 still puts a bit of a dent in your pocketbook.
All efforts are made to be welcoming. Nice atmosphere for families. Many kinds of food options-- from pizza -- carvery sandwiches -- Mac and cheese -- ice...


More  



Came for the annual car show. Always great and lots of fun. The set up is really cool with old and new cars. Also a place to even test drive a car if your interested in buying.

we got to a game , first time in this field , and i was treated like a king , very kind staff , they head me to the administration office , give me certification , and everybody that I told that im from Brazil, say to me thank you to come

The headlines were along the lines of "Hisashi Iwakuma throws the 5th Seattle Mariners no-hitter" and so forth. It was August 12, 2015. I was there, next to the Orioles dugout. Perfect seats. So, that was a great experience, right? But even if here was no dramatic event like a no hitter, Safeco Filed is such a fun, intimate experience...


More  



As for most ballparks, can't beat a sunny ball game, but Safeco has that extra great feel. There are so many varieties of food and the best thing is that the quality of the food is great (get an order of garlic fries). Ice cold beers in the aluminum cans are a hit. Hearing the train horn and the rumbling...

title: Sky View Observatory, Seattle
address: 701 Fifth Ave, 73rd floor, Columbia Center, Seattle, WA 98104 (Formerly Bank of America Tower)
review_list:
The only better view is from an airplane. The 73rd floor observatory provides a panoramac view of Seattle that you can' find anywhere else. Located on the top of a hill, the Columbia Tower is the tallest building in Seattle with by far the best view.

Came here with my girlfriend since we were staying close by and didn't want to trek it to the Space Needle. Plus, we read the views were better - people weren't lying! Skyview is wayy higher than the Space Needle and cheaper too! Definitely plan to come by here if its your first time in Seattle. My only regret is...


More  



Peaceful, beautiful, informative! You tower over the Space Needle. Elevator ride is split in 2 sections and exhilarating! Going again in a few weeks!

A must see when visiting Seattle. View's are great, and you get a free picture from the top of the Space Needle!

You have to come here. The view it's excellent. If you have to choose between here and space needle come here, it's less crowd. You will see a lot of information about the city.

The space needle has an appeal on its on so don't pass that to this, but if you have been to the needle, come here. We loved it. It was cloudy, but the views were still stunning. At twilight, they dimmed the lights inside which made it even better. The beer I had was actually very good and reasonable too!

We found a groupon which made this experience a good price. I wouldn't pay the full price to do this.
It's an awesome view though! They also have a little place to get snacks and drinks that are reasonable priced.

If you want to go as high up as you can in a building in the state of Washington, this is probably the place, immaculate views and for sure the tallest bulding in Seattle.
If you ask me this is on the list of places you just have to go in Seattle :-)

The space needle is everything you would expect. We had dinner up there as well so the ride up was free with a $35 meal.

We enjoyed our visit to the Sky View Observatory to see the views of Seattle and surrounds and to take some lovely photos. The photo, with superimposed backdrop, that you can get free of extra charge from your visit was a nice touch although a bit odd that we were there during the day and the backdrop was a night...

title: Kerry Park, Seattle
address: 250 W Highland Dr, Queen Ann Hill, Seattle, WA 98119
review_list:
Very beautiful night view of Seattle, a perfect place for photo lovers. Walk down steps, there are some nice restaurants along both sides of small streets.

Most every night one of the television stations uses this location as a backdrop for a story. Usually, a weather shot, though not always.
When our kids were young we used to take them to Kerry Park or Parson's Gardens most weekends.
As a frequent visitor to the play structures below we would pause up top, take in the view,...


More  



This provides one of the best views on land of the Seattle skyline, and highlighting the Space Needle, but can see the stadiums, Great Seattle Wheel and the Ferrys too, it's got a little bit of everything, great during a clear day, perfect spot to watch the sunrise or sunset, You will always see photographers here.

You can see Seattle skyline, space needle, Mt Rainier, Olympic national park and puget sound from here. I love this place!!!

I think this is a must for visitors. The view of the skyline, Sound, and Olympic Mountains is beautiful especially at sunset.

Went here on a grey day so unfortunately couldn't see the mountains, but this is a great vantage point to see the city skyline from. Would definitely check it out at sunset and other times with differect weather to get a wide range of photos. It's a small park so you won't be there that long, but well worth going...


More  



It's a must see. It's a little park but really nice and you jhave the best view of the Seattle skyline. Go on sunset if you can!

I LOVED THIS VIEW! You could really see the whole city, I went at night so pretty but I wish I went in the day time, because it was so cold.

I took good pictures from this place.... If you enjoy taking picture , it is a good place for takin picture... I was enjoying the view two hours over there ..... People have to go it.

Take your friends and family here when they visit the area, especially on a day when Mt. Rainier is visible. You will not be disappointed.

title: Hiram M. Chittenden Locks, Seattle
review_list:
One can learn the differences between lake level and sea-level as these locks open and close. Water flow is controlled and when the locks are loaded, water is released to drop boats leaving the sound, gates open and the flotilla departs - great spot to take your children and grand-children!

When ever we have out of state friends visiting, we always take them on a tour of Seattle. The Chittenden Locks is always on the list. Its amazing to see how the water is lowered and raised to bring boats from Lake Washington to the Puget Sound (or vice versa). My favorite time is on opening day of boating season...


More  



The locks are a fascinating place to take visitors, especially in August when the salmon are running in great numbers. The fish ladder is a real attraction, as is watching the locks work.

The Locks are a fun place to take visitors or to take your dog for a walk on Sunday. There is a nice park and visitors' center with bathrooms. It is fun to watch the boats go through the Locks and to see the fish in the fish ladder in season.

You must go see the Hiram Chittenden locks, AKA, Ballard locks.
The price is right!
It's free!
Never too crowded and always a show to watch. Either the fascinating way boats get from Elliott Bay to Lake Union or the salmon swimming in their desperate quest to lay eggs for future swimmers. One can witness the salmon in fish ladders...


More  



Living in Magnolia neighborhood, we always head to the locks from the South side. The view looking over into the botanical part of the locks is worth the perspective.
Fish Ladder (located on South side/Magnolia side):
- Head down below and watch the salmon running into Lake Washington. There are large glass windows and steps to let the little ones...


More  



Thus attraction is away from the Seattle city usual touring spots. You might even totally miss it. But it is actually a nice spot to see how ships from the "sea" side move into Lake Washington and the other way... the operation of the locks is pretty frequent due to ship traffic. It is nice for everyone to see first...


More  



An important part of the shipping story of the port of Seattle. Not crowded. If I like boating check it out we saw it in operation and they use no pumps...

I love it here. The lock canal setup is very interesting and I've seen seals here. The flying fish are very cool, as is the step ladder. Only thing is to check when the best time to go is.

This park not only highlights the locks, but has an idyllic strolling garden. The whole place is reminiscent of what a park would look like in the Victorian age. An excellent place for a casual walk.

title: Space Needle, Seattle
address: 400 Broad Street, Broad St. and Fifth Ave. N, Seattle, WA 98109
review_list:
Hum...just good! I thought 'My first trave will be happy,beautiful and meet many different people' when I saw this night view.
Actually I was afraid because U.S.A is sometimes filled with bad guys in the Hollywood's movies. But staffs was very kind in Space needle.
I recommend to see the night view at night. It is unbelievable!

It exactly as you would think it would be. I'm impressed at how well it has been kept up for being so old and it still has a very very strong customer base. I would recommend it to any one.

The tower was built in the early sixties but is just as it was then.If the weather is clear it is a great spot to good pictures of the city.

This was pretty underwhelming, but it was one of those things we felt like we had to do. For the cost, I'd skip it.

It's a cultural characteristic, and affords a great view of the city and the sound. The slow rotation in the restaurant is not noticeable. I recommend getting a reservation for just before sunset, using the valet parking and spending some time on the observation deck before going to eat. The staff is attentive and helpful with the menu and a...


More  



$22 for 1 person and you get an alright view with a couple of alright pictures. I found the gift shop more interesting. I personally will never go back to the top of the space needle.

For something that was built in 1962, this place has held up VERY well. It's an amazing structure that includes both a snack bar and a full-service restaurant-in-the-sky that's about 3/4 the way up. The 360 degree views from the circular observation deck were phenomenal, with very knowledgeable guides sprinkled everywhere.

Good view for the city, close to the market and ferry. And also here is another good place to see...........,.,,,,,,,,,,

If your visiting Seattle, how can you not visit the Space Needle. Built for the Worlds Fair, it is the one iconic symbol that everyone relates to the emerald city. You have two choices, either take the direct elevator to the top or make a reservation at the restaurant. The food has gotten better but you will be paying more...

Yes it's a city view, but why would you not go? The elevator is speedy, the staff is knowledgeable and once you reach the top you get a complete lay of the land. My teens loved it. We did visit later in the day so that any fog had lifted. All in we spent 30 minutes there and it was...

title: Seattle Public Library, Seattle
review_list:
Our hotel was located on the same street as the library so I decided to pop my head, with my camera attached to it, in. What a treat heading up to the tenth floor! Leading lines everywhere. Wished I had s model with me. Seattle has a serious homelessness issue and the library seemed to be a bit of a...


More  



The one thing that Seattle does not have are unique architectural building. The only exception is the EMP and the Seattle Public Library. Located between 4th and 5th avenue, it is a glass enclosed masterpiece. Highly recommended.

Perhaps the worst public space ever designed. The thought was to keep out the street drunks using putrid colors and dizzying layout. The librarians themselves rock. The collections are extensive and well maintained. The programs are engines of our city. But the building could be better razed and replaced with stacks of cargo containers.

This is the best library I've ever been in, architecture is fabulous along with the great staff. This is a great spot for rainy day weekend!!

This building is BEAUTIFUL inside and out! Take the time in your visit to Seattle to walk and enjoy this building. Plus, hey, it's free! Great photo opps.

This is such a distinctive architecture and whenever you are in Seattle, once you see this building you know exactly where you are. The architect designed this as a relatively young man. One would never have guessed that this is a library.

Libraries arent generally on my "must see" list while traveling, but I am glad that we visited.
This library is HUGE, and its a cool building .. im not sure how user friendly it is?-it seemed like finding a specific book here wld be a nightmare.
The tourist part of this place is the top floor, where you get cool...

In my opinion Seattle Public Library is the best Library in the world.... It has a great atmosphere... The staff is so friendly... English talk time is helpful too... Highly recommended .... If you visit Seattle you have to go it...

Going to a library on vacation is not everyone's idea of fun, but I highly recommend it! This library is beautiful and so unique! It has 10 floors that are worth checking out; each has interesting features worth seeing. It's free, though it's easy to spend a lot in the gift shop if you love words/books (or have friends and...

I am an architecture fanatic and book lover, so visiting libraries is always on my travel list.
Amazing building by Koolhaas, with lots of neon color accents, nice views and hidden spaces.
Loved the gift shop! All kinds of little stickers, must-have objects and even second hand books.
must see/do!

title: Benaroya Hall, Seattle
review_list:
The sound design of Seattle's symphony hall is worth every bit of the ticket price! Vibrant, relevant, irreverent productions one after another -- symphonic music in Seattle is very much in stride. Well worth an evening or many.

Had a great evening with the Seattle Symphony and a Great Beatles Tribute Group playing the music i grew up with.

Once we sat in the last row and could hear every note like we were in the first row. Another time we sat in the balcony overlooking the performer and it was like sitting in his lap.

While the Seattle Symphony's home is at Benaroya Hall, the Seattle Philharmonic also perform here! The latest concert featured a rare and rousing performance of the Symphony No. 1 by Antal Dorati. The music demands note accuracy and intonation from all sections of the orchestra which this group accomplished with flair. In spite of the indifferent acoustics of the room,...


More  



inside is very nice. outside is major bus stops. many people and homeless all wait outside. made the area is too crowed.

I was recently here for the holidays, for the Holiday Pops show, and it was my first time. The space was beautiful and the musicians were amazing. The interior is modern with clean lines, but comfortable with a warm color palette. Would definitely recommend to anyone visiting.

A beautiful environment for music, but the sound has disappointed my husband and I every time. Maybe our expectations have been too high--he attended so many Santa Fe Operas, I enjoyed Boston. But the acoustics have not been what we enjoy, regardless of our seating.

This is a wonderful place and I doubt if there is a bad seat in the house. The seat are comfortable with lots of room to spread out. No problem having a middle seat here as one is not crowded and can get up to visit the rest room and not disturb your neighbor. Excellent acoustics too.

Great place to hear great and unusual music. One time we watched the Matrix while they played the music. Awesome!

Whether it's the Holiday Special shows, Favorites Artists or Book Authors, this venue is superb! Great acoustics!

title: Green Lake Park, Seattle
address: 7201 East Green Lake Drive, Seattle, WA
review_list:
A nice little gem in the burbs for a stroll. If you're in the area and need to stretch your legs this is a great pit stop with a few food venues. Once upon a time I lived here, not sure I would travel here to see it, but as I said if you're in the area it's a great...


More  



Saved from the wrecking ball in the 1950's, Green Lake park is the jewel of the Seattle park system. Located in the middle of the city, the park offers swimming, jogging, sports and even a short (9) hole golf course. Just a great place to visit.

A beautiful park North of downtown Seattle. If you enjoy exercise when you travel, plan on running or walking around Green Lake. There is a paved path that encircles the lake and it wide enough to allow walking, running and biking. At one end of the lake is a boat house and frequently there are rowing (crew) teams practicing or...


More  



You can go for a long walk enjoy the view of the lake feed the ducks walk your dog ride a bike anything you would want to do children friendly safe place

I live just a 15-minute run from Greenlake, so I try to go several times a week. It is always vibrant all year round, with slackliners, yoga outside, soccer and volleyball games, and some of the best people-watching in Seattle! I also love seeing all the cute dogs that visit the park. :-)

Great place to come with the family and take a walk or play at the park. Local coffee shops across the stree, Starbucks and Pete's.

Seattle luxuriates in beautiful parks. Green Lake is among the best. It nicely accommodates walkers and runners. (Cyclists sort of dominate those on foot.) Dog-friendly (on a leash). The lake is scenic and, in fine weather, it's great for swimming and boating.

this was our go-to place for a bike ride, long walk, or just a place to put down a blanket and watch the world go by. if only the walkers would stick to the walking side of the path!

Whenever we are in Seattle visiting family in the Green Lake neighborhood, we always look forward to going out to walk around Green Lake. It is family friendly, dog friendly (as is all of Seattle), beautiful, scenic, a great place to view local and migratory birds. It is available year-round, with a small beach and boating, weather permitting. Nearby shops,...


More  



This is a great place to go for a stroll, people watching, or a picnic. It's in one of the most coveted neighborhoods of the city and is also loved by dogs.

title: University of Washington, Seattle
review_list:
Even the rain couldn't hide the beauty of this campus. We loved it!!! The library is a must see and the stadium made my sons heart race!

The University of Washington may have one of the prettiest campuses in the United States. The brick buildings set intimately within a beautiful garden setting makes it a great place just to walk through. Red Square is a sight to behold as is the entire campus. Highly recommended.

It was raining but still enjoyed our walking in the campus. Nice cafe and the Library is really like Harry Potters!

UW is a beautiful campus with lovely buildings and landscaping. The view from Red Square looking over Drumheller fountain at Mt. Rainer is outstanding. And excellent place to take out-of-town visitors for an afternoon.

I really enjoyed walking through this campus, and had more fun walking here than in UDistrict. The campus is large and very walkable. The architecture looks great, and differs for each building. I went to UW on a college visit for my sister. The building were so historically beautiful and I really hope she goes to this school.

I went to library and it's really great after that, I just walk around the campus. It's not so hard from downtown seattle to take bus to university and you can also take bus to Fremont!

In spring, the cherry blossoms are well worth the visit. At other times, the campus is a beautiful place to walk and to observe the curious habits of collegiate.

This is where my husband had his bachelor's degree and he was happy to tour us around. We had fun getting around the campus. Huge graduate school library and we can see Mt. Rainier when we went towards where the fountain was located in the campus. My daughter enjoyed the tour and so was I.

Located right on the edge of lake Union, this gorgeous Local campus offers exceptional opportunities to learn, work, or just visit one of Washington States Premier educational facilities. With walking paths and bike Trails located throughout, this campus provides an opportunity to experience a beautifully groomed campus with local fauna only a hop skip and a jump away from a...

We've lived in the Seattle area for well over a decade yet for some reason hadn't ever made it to Discovery Park before this past weekend. I actually visited here back in July of 2012 but I don't think it's changed a great deal. There were many walking trails that led down to the...

The Pacific Northwest at its best. We hiked early Saturday and nearly had the place to ourselves. Wish I had brought my dog!

Pleasant park with plenty of trails and scenery. Pet and children friendly. Fantastic views of the sound. Great place for an adventure!

Continuing on our quest of exploring the parks of Seattle, this Saturday we went to Discovery Park. I have been there a lot and mainly for runs on the trail or on the beach. But this was my wife's second trip to Discovery Park. The weather was chilly but to our good fortune Sun was out and it was a...

This park is the largest park in the City of Seattle, 500 + acres.
We love to come here to hike down to the Lighthouse, and trek back up to see the humungous trees.

Beautiful park with well taken care of trails. The views of the Puget Sound were beautiful and lots of interesting aircraft flying overhead.

Discovery is a large and beautiful overlooking the Puget Sound. It contains ample scenic trails. In places they run along a high cliff near the water.

The views are beautiful and we had a wonderful day at Discovery Park, but better directions would have been appreciated! We went to the visitor's center and they offered us a map, but we found it difficult to read, and ended up on a path that was extremely steep. The hike was worth it though for some of those views!

Whether you need deep forest chill time or the beach this is a great park to visit. Vast and full of a variety of situations, perfect for a long walk adventure and fun even a couple play areas for small kids.

title: EMP Museum, Seattle
address: 325 5th Avenue N, Seattle Center, Seattle, WA 98109
review_list:
Do you like fantasy, sci fi, gaming, or music? If so, this place is a must for you. Great interactive exhibits and play spaces on those topics, with some amazing costumes and other artifacts from key fantasy and sci fi movies. I could have easily spent 4-5 hours there rather than the 2 hours we had available. Cool shops with...


More  



Only 3 exhibits relating to music while we were there. One on Nirvana, one on Jimmy Hendricks and one on Guitars. If you like a hallway filled with hello kitty stuff, and one filled with sci-fi stuff well then you found your place

EMP is nestled in a congenial cluster along with Seattle Center and the Pacific Science Center. A family could spend a whole weekend in this general area, along with nearby Queen Anne, and not get bored. Downstairs is a restaurant, which I have never used; a special presentation area with seasonally changing displays, generally a tribute to one particular artist...


More  



If you are going to the Space Needle (likely), then the EMP is a stone’s throw away. It’s the funky looking building the other side of the monorail. The $25 entry fee is quite steep considering its limited contents and it can be whizzed around quite quickly; but if you are there already, why not? If you like Nirvana or...


More  



On first visit to Seattle, Uber driver recommended this place when we had a couple of hours free the first morning. It's kind of expensive - $42 for kid and myself. The coolest part is the sound lab - several sound booths, each with a unique experience. You have 10 minutes in the booth. Things like learn to play blues...


More  



I have been here several times and never been disappointed. They roll through different exhibits throughout the year like any museum and then they have there staples... If you are a Jimi Hendrix fan you will be pleased for sure. Really like the hands on sound rooms its always a hit with kids and teens along. Always something new and...


More  



I read mixed reviews on this museum but decided to check it out once I took a look at the outside of it after going up the Space Needle. Being a photographer, what intrigued me the most was the architecture (no flash photos are allowed). I'm a bit of a geek as well so the sci fo section made me...


More  



If you are a music historian, this is the place to go. If you just want to learn more about Rock n Roll and the superstars of the 60's and 70's, the EMP is worth spending an afternoon at. The architecture of the building is unique and the guitar chandileer is something to behold. Highly recommended.

Unfortunately not much to see here. What should be a "museum" looks more like a big collection of junk.

A "must to see" when in Seattle.
The collection of Jimi Hendrix and Nirvana memorabilia really worth the price of the ticket.

title: CenturyLink Field, Seattle
address: Junction of I-5 and I-90, Seattle, WA
review_list:
Home of the Seattle Seahawks and Sounders, you can't find a more electric and loud place to go than Century Link Field. Lots of open space and plentiful restrooms, this is the place to go if you want to find a great sports arena.

A very nice stadium and great place to watch the Sounders or Seahawks game. Clean, well kept and comfortable stadium. Prices are expensive but not any more so than other stadium type locations.

I am a lifelong football fan and have been to many college and pro stadiums. This one is the best ( I wasn't a Seahawks fan but am now). We were in town visiting friends and decided to catch a game. The fans were super hyped up for a PRE-SEASON game. The stadium is beautiful and as loud as advertised....


More  



We bought seasons tickets for the Seahawks 2015 season in the front row of Section 306 which were great. The roof awning just reaches out far enough that if you have Loge Seats in the upper 300 levels on the east and west sidelines, you're covered from the rain unless it's blowing really hard. People below us in the 100...


More  



The tours of the stadium have to be booked in person. We only had 3 days in Seattle and were not willing to risk not getting a tour at the time we needed.
To secure a tour, we paid for a private tour for our family of 3. The great thing about a tour is the ability to bring more...


More  



Home of the super bowl 48 champion Seahawks. If you haven't been to a game you must come to feel the electricity and the noise!! Where else can you create and earthquake or set s record for loudest fans. The electricity is amazing especially for a playoff game!!

There are signs around, but not very well marked to find parking garage. We were on 4th, then on 1st, and it is tricky, I think,+ to find the parking garage. The road splits for deliveries, then up for garage. I think this should be addressed and signage should be better established.

if you are a Seahawk Fan, you better visit the place, especially if there is a game. I visited in Jan, unfortunately there were no games to be played at that time, there is a shop next to the field, make sure you pass by to pick up what you can from SeaHawk accessories and clothes.

Went to the Boat Show at Century Link Field. Lots of different types of boats, small, big yachts, stuff.

I didn't really think it would be as loud as they say. It was though. We went with a group of Bears fans for the Bears vs. Seahawks. All of the fans were pretty nice to us and it was a pretty cool atmosphere. Plus they let you bring in your own food!

title: Washington Park Arboretum, Seattle
review_list:
I used to live a few blocks from the Washington Park Arboretum and, now that I've moved to another section of Seattle, I feel like I wasted an opportunity to get more out of the park.
Great for a run or nature walk, the arboretum is absolutely gorgeous. My wife and I took some family over there recently. We wanted...


More  



The Washington Arboretum is a wonderful place for an afternoon drive. It consists of many NW plants that have been cultivated by UW students and botanists. My favorite part of the museum is the Japanese Gardens. It is well worth the trip.

Visited on a rainy winter day, so not much was in bloom. But the walk was pleasant, the area green, and the park a nice respite from the crowded city.

A lovely placeto go for a relaxing day or afternoon, educative and beautiful. Learn about nature and especially enjoy learning all the types of trees. Take a picnic and sit and relax and enjoy. Popular in the wekend but friendly family atmosphere

The Arboretum is a wonderful place to visit. Walking amidst the gardens at any time of year is a pleasure.

Went to the Center for Urban Horticulture for 2 hours, then here for 2. Very nice arboretum. Lots of species to look at. Expect to do some walking.

Azalea Way is a wonderful stroll when the flowers are in bloom. In spring it's cherries, plums, azaleas. The Japanese garden across the street is worth a visit too.

The Washington Park Arboretum (managed by the University of Washington) is one of the largest parks in Seattle. The park is bisected by one through road which branches to parking near a visitor center as well as the Japanese Gardens. However, on a warm day when there hasn't been rain recently it can be a real chore to find parking,...


More  



Soon, very soon, the lovely winter garden will be in bloom. An easy walk from the parking lot and while any walk in this garden is great, the lovely, kind of tucked away winter garden is a very special thing. It rains here, sometimes for months and months and it is more often than not grey, grey, grey. But a...


More  



Too much to see in a few minutes. Help is available with signs, staff, volunteers, and fellow. Check their schedule for special events. Park is situated along an old creek which empties into a bay of Lake Washington that was lowered the level of Lake Union when the ship canal was constructed.

title: Seattle Center, Seattle
review_list:
The Seattle Center was created for the Worlds Fair and has been maintained as the center piece of Seattle. It has all kinds of exhibits and many functions, including Bumper-Shoot and Bite of Seattle. Its worth a whole day trip. Included is the EMP museum, Childrens Theatre and Key Arena

This was a fun place. While I do appreciate the fine glass works of Dale Chihuly we should not be charged so much just to see his "garden" of glass.

I've been coming here since the original World's fair in 1962. The Science museum is an awesome place to take kids, and the IMAX theatre is great - especially if you go Friday night to see all three of the most popular IMAX movies involving flight and space travel - and is cheap as well. The Food court is a...


More  



Easy and fast way to get from Hotels in Seattle to the Central Seattle where most of the main attractions are located. Also price for seniors is good. You don't have to wait a lot for the next monorail to take you back.

Riding the monorail was a great adventure for us. It is good shape for transportation with the age. I love the whole history to has. I would recommend doing this with your kids.

We took the monorail from the Space Needle to Seattle Center for $1.00 per person (senior fare) which put us in the heart of the shopping center and three blocks from our hotel. The Center has a great variety of shops and a wonderful food court as well.

prime area for tourists. Major Museums , Space needle , Shopping , Theatre at one Place. Museums include Children Museum , Chihuly Glass & EMP Museum.
Cant go wrong with this

The Seattle Center is a destination for a variety of activities. A picnic at the International Fountain on a sunny day can't be beat. There is also the Pacific Science Center. Step into the 1963 Worlds Fair architecture. There are plenty of outdoor benches and one of the best views of the Space Needle. Ride to the top for lunch,...


More  



Beautiful area, lots to see and experience in the area. Loved the water feature, music, mono rail and Amoury for good quick eats.

Space Needle, Chihuly Garden of Glass and several museums here. Terrific playground for kids. Monorail stops here from downtown Seattle.

title: Museum of History & Industry, Seattle
review_list:
I visited the old MOHAI - this is the new one on the south shore of Lake Union. Very impressed. Lots of Seattle/Washington history from native peoples through the 1700's through today. Some fun things for kids but lots of interesting pictures and exhibits for adults. Can easily spend a couple of hours especially if you like history.

The most fascinating for me was the sculpture of the historic schooner Wawona, built in 1896, it weights 11,000 pounds and is 65 ft. tall, reoriented vertically and dipping below into Lake Union. Also Boeing's history, the dot com bust, the marine exhibit on the fourth floor, Bezos Center for Innovation etc. Don't miss the introductory video, and the short...


More  



We had not visited the museum since they moved it to the new location. It's now right on Lake Union. The parking situation is quite a mess (as south Lake Union is a mess now) but we eventually figured out MOHAI does not offer general parking. you must either park in a pay lot or on the street. The exhibits...


More  



We are from Seattle and finally got down to MOHAI's new home on Lake Union. It is excellent! Don't miss the movie on the Great Seattle Fire, a funny and engaging presentation!

The old Armory has been completely renovated and they did a great job. The museum has lots of pertinent and interesting displays about early Seattle. Very well done and in a nice location.

Fine location adjacent to too ship and boat museums, with lovely building and good collection of local historical artifacts. The 2015 prohibition exhibit was highly entertaining.

There was a model train expo going on while we were visiting so there were numerous children in there. Fun to watch, but wanted to move quickly. In doing so, missed out on several things. Seemed like a messy cluster due to number of people and exhibits. Advice - Do not go visit for relaxation during this expo unless you...


More  



Good for a half-day tour. I think we looked at all the exhibits in under 4 hours. Very interesting history. Best to start at top floor and work your way down in clock-wise fashion.

This was our first visit to this museum. It was two hours well spent as we got a very good overview of the history of Seattle. I learned a number of new things about the city.

Smashing displays to show you the history of Seattle. Very well laid out and very good value for money. We thought we'd only be there for about an hour but we got engrossed and spent about 3 hours here. It's an easy bus ride from downtown. Definitely recommended

title: Woodland Park Zoo, Seattle
review_list:
The Woodland Park Zoo is a great place to take kids. It is worth a full day of adventure. The animals are well treated and it is reasonable priced. Also plan on visiting the Rose garden during the summer. Beautifully maintained.

Before they started charging for parking and when there were actually some animals to see. Thanks to all the bleeding hearts the monkey house is gone (don't miss that smell) among many if not most other exhibits.
At this point we might as well just set the rest of the animals free, close the zoo, erect a monument in it's...


More  



The Woodland Park Zoo is a great place to take the family. Our 10 year old enjoyed himself and the weather was very nice on this day. The food is a bit on the pricey side, but has good taste. The zoo is very clean and we would definitely come back the next time we visit Seattle.

I've been to this museum a few times with my family (3 small kids), and it's pretty good. I'd have to say I prefer visiting the Point Defiance Zoo better, because it seemed to have more animals on display.

This is a great zoo. The animals all have gigantic enclosures and seem like they are well taken after. Favorite animals were the tamarins, orangutan, meerkats, turtle/ tortoises, otters and the komodo dragon. The zoo does a great job of educating guests on the threat level to the animals and gives visitors an understanding of conservation efforts around the world....


More  



Living in a major urban center that encourages a love for all Life is just one of the benefits of living in Seattle. The Zoo, located in the beautiful Phinney Ridge neighborhood offers a range of activities that go far beyond the incredible animal sanctuaries. Wonderful exhibit displays back drop for incredible animals are just some of the reasons why...


More  



Whether you have kids or just like looking at animals the Woodland park zoo in Seattle is a great place go. The exhibits are modern and gives the xoo goer a chance to see the animals in a natural habitat. The new tiger exhibit is very good and gives you the opportunity too see them up close and personal through...


More  



The zoo is a super day for anyone from the solo traveler to an entire family. They are completely about conservation which really delights me. The only down side is the white wolf display seems really limited on room for what they need. A fun plus is you can feed penguins or the birds.

My wife loves, loves, loves to visit the zoo. We now live within walking distance so we have visited a lot lately. We've fed the giraffes but missed the feeding of the penguins (we'll try again later). For the second year in a row, we've attended the holiday lights event and thoroughly enjoyed it.

The zoo is cool lots of different animals to see and learn about but once you have been once you have seen it all.

title: Alki Beach, Seattle
review_list:
I have been visiting Alki for many years. If we are in town and need to stroll or wanting to snap a few pictures of the Seattle skyline this is the area to do it from. It's wonderful both by day or night with the lights of Seattle shining on the bay. Rain or shine we visit. Lots of little...


More  



Alki Beach for play ie...volleyball, running, rollar skating. A beautiful walk along the promenade with a cup of coffee. A wonderful way to spend any day.

Alki Beach is somewhat difficult to get to but is well worth the trip. On sunny days, the beach is filled with young people playing volleyball and having fun. The beach goes on forever and has some of the best restaurants in the city. Salty's is my favorite.

I love bringing my friends and family here for fresh sea air and breath taking views! Wonderful place to bring your special someone. Peaceful and romantic! Family picnics and bonfires are nice too!

O good beach close to the city. It gets packed in the summertime, you can play volleyball, it has nice ice cream shops around, sand is real sand and not stones, which is rare here around.

Every weekend s a candidate for a great adventure, but sometimes a walk on the beech is just what a person needs to feel ONE with the Earth.. Al;ki is one such place, where a coffee and a long walk with a friend is like a trip to Home.

Alki Beach is close to West Seattle, with great views back to the city skyline. Sunday brunch at Salty's is a treat when we have been up visiting family. Beach days can be precious in Seattle, so it is great to know where to maximize that opportunity.

I love Alki beach, no matter the season, as it always brings back fond memories of my childhood. When it's cold. I can stop at one of the various coffee places for hot cocoa or coffee for my companions, have breakfast or lunch, Blackcomb, or just sit and look at the water.

We enjoy traveling to West Seattle and checking out Alki all throughout the year. In the summer months, it does tend to get a bit crowded, but that is only because it is such a fun place to go during those warm sunny days.

What more could you ask for? This is a great beach area at almost any time of year, with restaurants to relax in, beach to kick back in, the smell of evening firepits burning (get yours early) clear running and walking trails. Try to do it other than a peak summer weekend day as it does get a bit crazy...

title: Klondike Gold Rush National Historical Park, Seattle
review_list:
Small but pleasant and informative museum. Great movie outling the Gold Rush. Free admittance and very nice attendants. Hands on exhibits - great for kids and adults.

Quite in depth and good theatre. 2 floors and kept us amused for about 90 mins. Interesting stories about the gold rush.

This museum is a sadly missed visit by so many! It has many interactive stations for all ages. The museum is free to visitors and I would encourage anyone to take the time to visit. My husband and I only had 30 minutes, but definitely worth our time. We'll bring folks back to this gem.

A museum that's not overwhelming in size or scope, not crowded. Helpful docents. Well laid out in a contemporary interior. Brings the people of the era to life with stories and photos. I think older kids would get a kick out of it, but we were a party of adults. Recommend.

Interesting exhibits about the gold rush and from the time of the gold rush. Rangers available to answer your questions.

This is a tucked away museum but worth a visit. It may take about an hour and a half to see the displays and get insight into the people of the Gold Rush.

This park tells you a lot in a relatively small space. The exhibits are cleverly arranged and make to flow through the display areas very efficient. At least, when there isn't a school group in attendance.
The amazing sets of figures that are presented about the Klondike Gold Rush are staggering. The number of people, the supplies and the amazing...


More  



This was recommended to us as a free, small history lesson. We were there about 45 minutes, and we learned a lot about the Klondike Gold Rush and those involved in it! Great for families!

Very well laid out exhibits. They do have a strong school field trip program, which would have been annoying if there had been students there, but the place was pretty much empty. Rangers were very receptive to my remark that their picture of the Tlingit, while historically accurate, gave a mis-impression of traditional Tlingit houses.

This museum ties Canadian and US history together through the development of the Klondike gold rush and Seattle. It's free, which is good, because you'll pay dearly for parking. The museum has a gold panning exhibition at 11:00. It is kid friendly and has two different booklets for children to complete while going through the museum. The 20 min. introductory...


More

title: Gas Works Park, Seattle
review_list:
Gas Works Park has a wonderful view of downtown Seattle. It also is the perfect place to watch the 4th of July Fireworks. Highly recommended

Stopped here after a fun Seattle Saturday and brought a football to play catch with the kids. The view of downtown was nice, however couldn't really enjoy the park as there was goose poop everywhere! I know it's not exactly the park's fault, but it did detract from the enjoyment.

Gorgeous day and cool old gasworks made this park unique. We walked to the waterfront and had a view of downtown Seattle and a mini sailboat regatta in progress. Spectators watched as a guy (unsuccessfully) tried to take flight in a glider contraption. Easy parking. Great for taking photos.

I visited the park on a sunny day in early February and had the place nearly all to myself. The park offers stunning views of the downtown from across Lake Union. I suggest making a little time for this great photo op!

Short walk from Fremont Brewing company. Great views of Seattle skyline, houseboats, etc, got to watch Modern day Knights in combat..... Not sure if they were practicing for a competition or just having fun in the park!

Go to the Essential Baking Company, grab a coffee and a treat, and see if you can tell what to throw where in the different trash cans they have. But bring your coffee to gasworks park. It's another interesting and unique spot in Seattle. A place to sit and watch the boats go by and guess which houseboat across the...


More  



This is where you want to be on the 4th of July, wide open spaces and a great place for the kids to run.

I've never understood the draw to this park, but there is a fierce loyalty for those who like it here so I won't criticize. I DOES have amazing views which is something I can appreciate. The few times I've been here there's either been a wedding pictures being taken or engagement photos being done. . . so it's certainly a...


More  



This is truly a genius and beautiful park. Getting to walk around this magnificent set of grassy hills and around the historic facility gives such an aesthetic feeling. The views of Seattle are also stunning.

Wonderful views of Lake Union and the Seattle skyline. Beautiful place to walk or picnic. (Or, on July 4th, to join a billion other people to watch the fireworks display.)

title: Seattle Art Museum, Seattle
address: 1300 1st Avenue, Between Union & University Street, Seattle, WA 98101-2902
review_list:
We hadn't been to SAM in many years and decided to catch the Impressionism exhibit on the last day. SO easy to purchase timed tickets online and skip the crowds. The exhibit was very busy but we were able to hear the docent tour and enjoy learning more about the artists. We also toured the other exhibits which are always...


More  



The recently opened Kehinde Wiley exhibit at Seattle Art Museum is outstandingly thought provoking, colorful and simply magnificent. The scale of many of the pieces is such that you have to see them in person to truly appreciate how much work must have gone into each canvas. The juxtaposition of contemporary figures, many adorned in hip hop attire, striking classic...


More  



I just saw the new Kehinde Wiley show and was amazed how wonderful his work is. Large colorful canvases depicting well... in his own words... "The history of painting by and large has pictured very few black and brown people, and in particular very few black men. My interest in these paintings is countering that absence." This is a must...


More  



Love this place. Try to go during a weekday - a little busy on weekends. New displays all of the time, as well as old favorites!

Their hours have decreased in recent years, as have staff. Apparently having financial difficulties and selling off some of its property for other use. Unfortunate.

Good museum but only spent about an hour inside. Depending on which exhibitions they have in rotation, it makes it more or less interesting. Staff was very friendly.

A nice museum on mostly 2 floors of exhibit space. Nice modern facility with open rooms for a varied amount of artwork ranging from Islamic to African to Asian to American Art.

I thoroughly enjoyed visiting the Seattle Art Museum. The variety of exhibits would satisfy almost any museum-goer. Art ranged from African cultural masks to Pacific Northwest glass blowing, to paintings by masters.

Gorgeous modern and light filled museum. Filled with outrageously modern exhibits like suspended cars.

You can go and have a great time, with the family or alone, they have many rooms to visit you better have time to go there, and see everything.

title: Pike Place Fish Market, Seattle
review_list:
The Pike Place Market's fish market is a great place to visit at anytime of the year! You go downtown and get whatever fresh off the boat seafood that you want. It's a beautiful experience, to get your fish and bring it home and cook it.

4 of us went here to get some crab cocktails. So many places serve it but we went to the flying fish place because they had the added entertainment. Fruits, veggies, flowers, souvenirs and of course plenty of seafood for sale here. The original Starbucks is right across the street from this area. All covered in case of rain

I enjoyed my time here to discover the food and shops at this fish market. There is a place through fishes from distance for their clients. I really enjoy the walk and see what's going on here. even though i just stop over at seattle, I picked this spot for my short stay.. I am glad I came and I...


More  



Pike Place Market is an iconic Seattle landmark. Not only are there several fish mongers, but florists, vegetable stands and quite a few artisans. While I rarely pick up fish to fly home to Virginia, I often pick up some vegetables to fix when I get back.

Part of the Pike Place Market. You could definitely skip but , you will visit Pike Place Market anyhow for other things to see . But this is seriously overcrowded and smelly.
The Show of flying fish is overrated , but did I mention it's free :) :) :)

We walked over as the Market was opening. Colorful, both the people and the merchandise. Plenty to see beside the fish.

This is not just a fish market, it's a consortium of booths and stalls selling all sorts of other foods and sundries. Not to miss if it's a first trip to Seattle.

Commenting solely on their presentation, the fish look fresh, the staff seem friendly, and the service seems top-notch. From a tourist's perspective, I think everyone should visit the unique market during their Seattle visit. From a customer's perspective (though I have never purchased their fish), I am impressed with their selection of fish and customer service.

The world-famous home of flying fish, Pike Place Fish Market is one of Seattle's most beloved tourist attractions.
When someone purchases a fish, one of them will throw it in the air to another to be wrapped up for the customer.
It was amazing! A must see.

In town for business meeting and as luck would have it our meeting room overlooked this amazing, busy fish market with numerous shops, street entertainment, and especially the fish mongers throwing fish! Plus a gigantic brass pig. What more could you ask for! Produce and fish displays were gorgeous. Perhaps monk fish scared a few kids. Really a treat.

title: Seattle Great Wheel, Seattle
review_list:
First let me say that I've been on the London Eye and the Las Vegas High Roller. This is not on that caliber of wheel. It is close to $15 with tax, but it is basically a carnival Ferris wheel only with an enclosed cabin that seats max of 8 people per cabin. You are not supposed to change seats...


More  



One of those things that one should do at least once while in the area. Nice view of the waterfront.

I am not a big fan of Ferris Wheels but my wife loves them. We had a few hours in Seattle on a Saturday morning so after walking around Pikes market decided to walk down to the waterfront. It was a mild, sunny day, so I was talked into going on the Wheel. It was definitely worth it. Great views...


More  



This ferris wheel is so much fun and a great thrill for all ages. Even if you have a fear of heights, you will be happy that you chose this adventure. There ar great views of the city and Elliott Bay. It is very smooth and calm. I am so happy we picked this as an activity. The light on...


More  



This is a must see & ride! We were there for Sunset I Loved Everything I Saw. The Modules are roomy and They are mostly see thru..Visions all around You..SO BEAUTIFUL

What could be better than giant ferris wheel by the water? We went at night and the lights of the city are beautiful, and it was a little scary going down looking like you are going into the dark water.

This was a huge challenge for me, it was quite windy and the wheel was very still. Now, my husband moving the dang seat back and forth was another story. Gorgeous view at night!! The bar next door was a great spot as well. So fun

Very comfortable, even for those of us with a fear of heights. The view of the city and the Sound are well worth the cost of a ticket. I have gone during the day and at night - both are wonderful.

This was fun, and an experience to try at least once while in Seattle! Best views if it's a nice day, but still fun and relaxing either way. I would say this could be a great romantic gesture.

Situated on Seattle Waterfront , you can experience almost similar views if you opt for the ferry tour which is less expensive. But if you have to do this , its good too. its a big Ferry wheel but not not even close to the London Wheel.

title: Kubota Garden, Seattle
review_list:
This park is located in South Seattle and does not get the credit it deserves. I lived in Seattle for over 30 years and only visited the Kubota Gardens last year. It very much reminds me of the Buchart Gardens in Victoria. Best time to go is the spring. Highly recommended.

This park is an oasis in the middle of Seattle. It is beautifully laid out and is overwhelmingly green. A picnic lunch would make for a nice retreat from the city while still in the city.

A very nice way to spend an hour or two on a beautiful day. The gardens are a great place to take a walk or sit and quietly chat with a friend.

Kubota Garden is the perfect place to take a relaxing walk or to just sit and reflect. It is very well marked, so you do not get lost.

This is one of the most idyllic places in the entire city. It is perfect for a date and romantic picnic!

This garden is located all by itself in south Seattle. Created by Mr. Kabota before WWII it is a garden to explore and contemplate. Rarely crowded, it is well maintained, quiet and tranquil.

These gardens are stunning and the perfect place to bring visitors new to Seattle. Spring, Fall, and Summer months are glorious here. Kids love it. A nice place to picnic or relax.

This is a true gem if you are looking for a place for relaxation, reflection, or simply a quick walk. Tucked snuggly in the neighborhood of the Renton Ave S; this Japanese garden offers a unique sanctuary. Walking across a pond on red bridge; sitting in the stone garden; or quick hiking loops around beautifully kept landscape, the choices are...


More  



I'll admit, we are quite spoiled with privately owned Chinese and Japanese Gardens in Portland, so our visit to the Kubota Gardens near Seattle were just okay. There is quite a bit of park to explore, which is nice, but when we went (February), they seemed to be doing a lot of construction. There were piles of dirt and muddy...


More  



This free park is an idyllic setting for weddings and families. There are trails and various water features, along with meadows and streams. It is a trip worth taking on cloudy days or sunny though the area seems best appreciated when the weather is clear.

title: Seattle Aquarium, Seattle
review_list:
Had a few hours to spend so I decided to go. It was octopus week when I went so there were extra activities. Loved the seals and otters (sea and river); the sea otters were being fed while I was there. Cafe had decent food, but the latte was not good.

I have been to this Aquarium many times, taking my children for school class trips. The Aquarium is small but still holds the interest of many children. For the last year, it has been difficult getting to the Museum due to all of the construction due to the Viaduct tunnel. If your going to spend a day at the waterfront,...


More  



I'm not sure I have been anywhere more depressing than this aquarium. Explore the rest of the Waterfront Pier area but skip this.

Several sea animals. Nice layout. Kids loved it. Good walk along the pier. Lot of construction in the area but signs are there which tell you where you can park.

I've been to a few aquariums on the West Coast, and the Seattle Aquarium is just ok. I didn't think it was very large, and it didn't have many sea creatures on display. I probably won't be visiting this aquarium in the near future.

title: Lake Washington, Seattle
review_list:

This is a really gigantic lake - I would have thought it was the sea until I was told otherwise. There is a floating bridge (or rather 2) to link up the two sides of Washington. So this place is really quite amazing

review_list:

title: Seattle Japanese Garden, Seattle
address: 1075 Lake Washington Blvd E, Seattle, WA 98112
review_list:
I have been here numerous times and it is beautiful every season. Maybe my favorite is fall. No, spring....well, summer...ok, I give up. It is just a lovely, restful and charming place that is a little bit of paradise. If you are a photographer, prepare to go crazy. However, tripods are only allowed on a few specific days.

Although this one is not so big but it is still beautiful. The trees, shrubs, the pathways, large koi fishes swimming in the ponds and the turtles too just made everything perfect. Always a nature lover so I am always excited to visit gardens when on a trip. Worth a visit if you love nature.

Beautifully designed Japanese garden, lovely pathways and feeding the fish was a very delightful experience.
one can spend hours in this peaceful place!

Maybe it's because i like the japanese aesthetic of perfecting nature, but this spot is pretty special. If you are into gardening or know someone who is, they will appreciate the effort that goes into making this look like a naturally occurring landscape. Great photos around every ben.

Early morning walk. A bit overpriced at $6.00 for a quick walk. However, the walk and the memory is worth a whole lot more than an overpriced cup of Starbucks. Sunny bright day in Seattle, just lucky I suppose.

we went in october but it's beautiful almost year round. Great job keeping everything trimmed and blooming optimally.

I have to say, that even in early winter (November) this is a beautiful and peaceful garden to walk through. Though half the trees don't have leaves, there area still others that stay in foliage and bloom year round here. Plus you have the serenity of the water, the fish and of course the turtles.
In my opinion this is...


More  



The Japanese Garden is always fun to visit. But at it's best in the spring and fall. It's a great place to take friends or family who are visiting Seattle. Normally there is plenty of parking.

Its a very quiet and relaxing spot and the Japanese maples of gold, orange and red were just awesome. The grounds keeping is perfect yet the leaves yet to be raked made for a beautiful sight both on the grass and floating down the streams. Highly recommend you visit during late October time of year.

The Japanese Garden in the Arboretum is absolutely beautiful. There is a small fee to enter the garden, but you can stay and stroll the paths all afternoon or to your heart's desire. It is right across the street from the Washington Park Arboretum (which is free), another great attraction. The garden and arboretum are particularly gorgeous in the fall.

title: Queen Anne Hill, Seattle

You will not be disappointed if you decide to get out and explore Queen Anne Hill. The neighborhood is beautiful. It offers excellent views of the sound and the city. There are some very nice small little parks that you will come across.

We were there today 27 Oct 2015 across the day. walking though the avenues and enjoying the sight of well built elegant homes on one side and Seattle views on the other. Would make a very good option for a children's school day out. There is also the added attraction that there is nothing they can spend on !!

Great way to walk off all your meals LOL!!
Seriously , beautiful scenery. I enjoyed getting up in the early am, would walk , meditate and drink my coffee

title: Seattle Theater Group- Paramount, Seattle
review_list:
I joined the Paramount Theater free tour in Seattle. It was on Monday morning and took around 2 -3 hours. The tour is organized by volunteers and there it is free tour.
The volunteer explained the history of the Theater and including how the Theater built, revamped. Although the Theater is nearly 100 year old, facilities inside were very modern...


More  



Just attended the opening of "Bullets Over Broadway" at the Paramount Theater.
The acting was first rate, and the live music added to the experience of attending a professional stage production. If you can't make it to Broadway, don't hesitate to experience a local venue that is classy all the way!

Theater was ornate and beautiful. Be advised...many stairs.
Great performance. Would highly recommend. We will be returning in March.

THE place for concerts and musical productions. This theatre has been renovated from the ground up (the free backstage tour is awesome) and has a variety of seating configurations, several bars, and a well-trained staff. It's been amazing to see this theatre grow from its shabby state in the 1970's to the world-class venue it is right now.

STG saved this historic theater from the wrecking ball, restored to it's original glory and hosts the best entertainment you can find anywhere. Register with STG & get advance notice on all the shows. We are particularly fond of Broadway musicals but also love rock & comedy concerts.

Great old theater in the heart of Seattle. It's a landmark of the city and is on the national historic register. It was opened in 1928 as the Seattle Theater. It is owned and operated by the Seattle Theatre Group, and has 3,000 seats. It was renamed the Paramount in the 1930s.It's worth snapping a few pictures.

This is a must see place in Seattle. Seeing a show here is out of this world. The building itself is breathtaking. The shows are awesome.

We went to see Three Acts, Two Dancers, One Radio Host which was a brand new experience. We had seats pretty far back but they were fantastic. It is a very historic old venue but it feels really fresh and modern inside. The parking was a little tough but we ended up looping around enough to catch a break fairly...


More  



If/Then, created to showcase her talents, shows the diversity in life based on minor decisions. Wow!

Fantastic show in GORGEOUS THEATRE!!! Broadway touring company with Tony Award-nominated cast is hard to beat, and the performance was excellent. The theatre was worthy of the show.

review_list:

Traver, conveniently across the street from the Seattle Art Museum, is a longtime outstanding gallery for NW art, and for us especially for glass. Singletary show when we were there was of course spectacular. Right in the midst of tourist Seattle, definitely worth a visit.

Did you know that Seattle has the most glassblowers per capita outside Murano? The glassblowing movement really came alive in the modern age in the Seattle area, prompted by the instruction and experimentation at Pilchuck (glass school outside Seattle) by artists like Lino Tagliapietra, Dale Chihuly, and Dante Marioni (among others), and promoted by Bill Traver with his gallery!
Exhibits...

title: Ross Park, Seattle
review_list:
This park is unique in that it has an upper and lower baseball field with backstops, scoreboard, a playground with some clever climbing features and monkey bars, baby swings, slide and a nice sized sand box to play in. Lots of grassy areas to play or relax and there are public bathrooms. The newest addition is the Ross Playfield Shelter...

This is a big neighborhood park with two ball fields (upper and lower) and basketball court, two state of the art play structures, a swing set, sand pit, bathrooms and a Shelter house that can be rented for parties, etc. The play structures are truly amazing and the kids had a great time playing on them.

There are also loads of beautiful homes and very well manicured lawns to walk by and enjoy.

review_list:

title: Schmitz Park, Seattle
review_list:
Schmitz Park is only a few blocks from Alki Beach so can be easily incorporated into a visit.
The park has peaceful trails, a nice stream, places to sit and picnic, and the most wonderful sense of peace and quiet. It is a wonderful oasis to get away from the noise and hubbub of Seattle.

Schmitz Park is a lovely woods. You can get "away from it all" and also see indigenous trees and other woodland plants.

title: Leschi Park, Seattle
address: 100 Lake Washington Blvd South, Seattle, WA 98122
review_list:
Perfect little swimming hole with Beautiful views. It has a grassy are for frisbee throwing and also rest rooms. The kids enjoyed the playground which is within walking distance. Downtown Leschi is right up the hill. We enjoyed our relaxing time there at the Park

Majestic trees, manicured expanses of grass and beds of fuchsias and roses are everywhere. The park is on a slope, stretching back and up to tennis courts and then continuing via trail deep into the woods. The park is on lake Washington and offers amazing sunsets and views of the Eastside.

title: Kobo, Seattle

When you come to Seattle bring your bike, rent one, or lace up your walking shoes.

title: Ward Johnson Winery, Seattle

title: Alki Park, Seattle
review_list:
The kids loved the beach. The views of Seattle were spectacular. However the beach itself was very very rocky and could use some imported sand. This place would be awesome!! However we loved it. The ferry to get there and back was quite expensive since we have three kids!

Reminded me of Mallory Square in Key West except the water is freezing. The views on the other hand will blow you away!!

title: Grand Army of the Republic Cemetery, Seattle
review_list:
The GAR cemetery holds the graves of 526 Civil War veterans who relocated to the Seattle area after the War. It is a peaceful place of rest that you should drop by while in Seattle.
The veterans represent 26 states both Union and Confederate, although Union states are in the majority.

title: Sunset Hill Park, Seattle
review_list: Seattle has a number of great view points but this park is one of the best. Views of the entire Olympic Mountain Range, Mount Rainier, Puget Sound, Blake & Vashon Islands, Discovery Park, West Point Lighthouse and Shilshole Marina. A few picnic tables and two different benches with gardens around them. A really beautiful setting.

title: Bergen Place Park, Seattle
review_list:
This concrete triangular-shaped plaza is located in Ballard between Leary Avenue, 22nd Avenue NW and Market Street. An information board describes the special relationship between Ballard and Scandinavia and explains that the park's name reflects Seattle's association with Bergen, Norway, its sister city. Flags from each Scandinavian country stand here and a huge mural depicts relevant scenes. For example, the...

Bergen Place park is a small park in the village center of the Ballard neighborhood. The park, named after Bergen Norway, celebrates the Scandinavian heritage of the neighborhood. It was dedicated in 1975 by King Olav V or Norway. The backdrop to the park is a mural by Alan Wylie and Charles Svob depicting scenes from Ballard's lumber and maritime...


More  



This town square/park was created in 1975 and was dedicated to King Olaf of Norway and named for Bergen, Norway, one of Seattle's sister cities. The park is home to Artist Jenn Lee Dixon's "Witness Trees" and a community information kiosk.

title: Helicopters Northwest, Seattle
review_list:
Received a groupon lesson as a gift. Very helpful and professional staff. Jez explained the whole process as well as describing what the certification process could look like. Esther sets the standard as a competent and calm instructor. Very customer focused. I enjoyed every minute and recommend it highly for anyone looking for a helicopter intro.

We purchased this trip from Groupon: 20 min for $141.00 [3 people] at arrival I as ask if we would like to extend our trip to 40/50 min for extra $100.00 and we did it.
Wonderful sights that you can only enjoy from a helicopter. Well worth the expense.

We took the longer ride (40 minutes) and had a really nice time. It was smooth and not scary at all. Our pilot was very knowledgeable of the area. Such a cool thing to do when visiting Seattle. title: Beneath the Streets, Seattle
review_list:
For a person visiting Seattle, the under ground tour provides you with an interesting history of Seattle. When we had the great fire, the city decided to build over the ruins. The tour is fascinating to see how people lived in the early part of the century. Highly recommended.

Had a great tour guide. Very enjoyable day in the underground even though it was raining quite hard.

Had a great tour of Pioneer Square underground. Anyone looking to learn a little bit more about Seattle will find value in this tour. Tour guide has a wealth of knowledge, personally I found his responses to the groups questions more interesting opposed to the more scripted parts.

As the story goes, the original streets of Seattle were covered and elevated to the 2nd floor of the bordering buildings creating an eerie complex of pathways and dead-ends. The narrated history tour is offered at specific times, but don't expect to discover some long lost secret.

I learned so much about Seattle at the turn of the last century. The guide was smart and funny. A great time was had by all.

This tour of old Seattle under the current businesses and streets was one of our highlights of visiting Seattle. The tour guides are very entertaining and share non stop Seattle historical stories from the last 150 years. One comes away really appreciating how Seattle became the city it is today and the struggle to build a fast growing city on...


More  



After seeing this and the other tour I can say that this one has the better guide and smaller group. It also did a great job showing more connection to the above ground parts of history.
Definitely a history tour. You need to be interested in seeing living history undergound. Its not a 'flashy' type of tourist trap. But it...
